image.altText: A view from above showing a building that has been destroyed.

items.synopsis: Most of the approximately 200 people kidnapped in Israel by Hamas terrorists on October 7 and taken to the Gaza Strip are still alive, Israel's military says.

title.children: Israel's military says 'majority' of hostages taken by Hamas are alive

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israel's defence minister says that one objective for the military campaign in the Gaza Strip is to end Israel's responsibility over the Palestinian coastal enclave. Defense Minister Yoav Gallant has made the remarks during a briefing to parliament's Foreign Affairs and Defense Committee, his office says. "Gallant detailed the objectives of the campaign, including the elimination of Hamas and destruction of both its military and governing capabilities, the complete removal of Israeli responsibility from the Gaza strip, and the creation of a new security reality in the region," the statement said. Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel says it aims to end its responsibility for the Gaza Strip

children.content: Israel's defence minister says that one objective for the military campaign in the Gaza Strip is to end Israel's responsibility over the Palestinian coastal enclave.
Defense Minister Yoav Gallant has made the remarks during a briefing to parliament's Foreign Affairs and Defense Committee, his office says.

"Gallant detailed the objectives of the campaign, including the elimination of Hamas and destruction of both its military and governing capabilities, the complete removal of Israeli responsibility from the Gaza strip, and the creation of a new security reality in the region," the statement said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ABC's global affairs editor John Lyons has just reported an update from Israel: "The IDF is saying that they believe the majority of the hostages taken into Gaza are alive," Lyons says. "We don't know more than that. We don't know where they are. "And, in fact, it's intriguing as to how they would have known that. Perhaps back channels, could be through Qatar as a mediator. "At least that is something hopeful, IDF saying the majority of the hostages in Gaza are alive." The news comes as Israeli troops and tanks gather near the border with Gaza ahead of a ground offensive, which Lyons said could happen this weekend.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Breaking: Israel says it believes most of the hostages taken into Gaza are still alive

children.content: The ABC's global affairs editor John Lyons has just reported an update from Israel:
"The IDF is saying that they believe the majority of the hostages taken into Gaza are alive," Lyons says.
"We don't know more than that. We don't know where they are.
"And, in fact, it's intriguing as to how they would have known that. Perhaps back channels, could be through Qatar as a mediator.
"At least that is something hopeful, IDF saying the majority of the hostages in Gaza are alive."
The news comes as Israeli troops and tanks gather near the border with Gaza ahead of a ground offensive, which Lyons said could happen this weekend.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: There are signs some Palestinians who moved south in response to the Israeli order to evacuate are returning to their homes, because air strikes are taking place in the south too, the UN human rights office says. “We remain very concerned that Israeli Forces’ heavy strikes are continuing across Gaza, including in the south,” spokesperson Ravina Shamdasani told reporters. “The strikes, coupled with extremely difficult living conditions in the south, appear to have pushed some to return to the north, despite the continuing heavy bombing there.” About one week ago Israel's miliary ordered about 1.1 civilians in northern Gaza to evacuate to the south, prompting the UN to warn of "devastating humanitarian consequences". Ms Shamdasani said the rights office had since heard accounts about people wanting to migrate back north, including from one unidentified Palestinian who said: “I might as well die in my own house.” Associated Press
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: After being told to flee to the south, the UN says some Palestinians are returning home

children.content: There are signs some Palestinians who moved south in response to the Israeli order to evacuate are returning to their homes, because air strikes are taking place in the south too, the UN human rights office says.
Northern Gazans were told to evacuate and travel south last week.
“We remain very concerned that Israeli Forces’ heavy strikes are continuing across Gaza, including in the south,” spokesperson Ravina Shamdasani told reporters.
“The strikes, coupled with extremely difficult living conditions in the south, appear to have pushed some to return to the north, despite the continuing heavy bombing there.”
About one week ago Israel's miliary ordered about 1.1 civilians in northern Gaza to evacuate to the south, prompting the UN to warn of "devastating humanitarian consequences".
Ms Shamdasani said the rights office had since heard accounts about people wanting to migrate back north, including from one unidentified Palestinian who said: “I might as well die in my own house.”

image.altText: Netanyahu and Biden are pictured holding each other while being surrounded by cameras and security

image.altText: A woman with a black t-shirt looks at the camera
